text:
# 6 Axis Articulated Arc Welding Robots
## TAWERS Series
### January 2018

----

## Continuously Evolving TAWERS!

### Models:
- **1g TAWERSI**
- **0 TAWERSI**

----

## The Arc Welding Robot System: TAWERS

### Types of TAWERS:
| Type               | Description                     |
|--------------------|---------------------------------|
| **Separate Type**  | TS series                      |
| **Through-Arm Type** | TM series                    |
| **External Type**  | TL series                      |

----

This document outlines the TAWERS series of 6-axis articulated arc welding robots, highlighting the evolution of the TAWERS models and providing a structured overview of the different types available.

# TAWERS Robot Systems with Integrated Welding Power Source Technology

## Torch
### Torch Type
- **Type Selectable**: Selectable to fit your application!
- **WGⅢ/WGHⅢ**

### TM Series
- **Models**: TM-1100, TM-1400, TM-1600, TM-1800, TM-2000

| Type                | TM-1100 | TM-1400 | TM-1600 | TM-1800 | TM-2000 |
|---------------------|---------|---------|---------|---------|---------|
| Separate Type       | -       | -       | ○       | ○       | ○       |
| Through-Arm Type    | ○       | ○       | ○       | ○       | ○       |
| External Type       | ○       | ○       | ○       | -       | -       |

### Payload Information
- **Space Saving & High Payload!**
- **Long-arm & High Payload!**

| Model | Payload (kg) |
|-------|--------------|
| TS-800| 8            |
| TS-950| 8            |
| TL-1800| 8           |
| TL-2000| 6           |

## Manipulator Lineup (as of January 2018)

| Series | TS 800 | TS 950 | TM 1100 | TM 1400 | TM 1600 | TM 1800 | TM 2000 | TL 1800 | TL 2000 |
|--------|--------|--------|---------|---------|---------|---------|---------|---------|---------|
| Separate Type       | -      | -      | ○       | ○       | ○       | ○       | ○       | -       | -       |
| Through-Arm Type    | ○      | ○      | ○       | ○       | ○       | ○       | ○       | -       | -       |
| External Type       | ○      | ○      | ○       | ○       | -       | -       | -       | ○       | ○       |
| Payload (kg)        | 8      | 8      | 6       | 4       | 6       | 8       | 6       | 8       | 6       |

### Rated Welding Output
- **WGⅢ**: 350 A @ 80% duty cycle (CV), 350 A @ 60% duty cycle (pulse).
- **WGHⅢ**: 450 A @ 100% duty cycle (CV/pulse).

# A Variety of Features Specialized for Arc Welding

## Feature 1: Enhanced Structure Specialized for Welding

### Basic Performance
- **Increased Motion Speed**:
- TM-1400: Speed of main 3 axes increased by 22% on average (approx. 42°/s more than TA type).

- **Extended Reach**:
- TM-1400: 1,437 mm (63 mm more than TA type).

### Arm Specialized for Welding
- **Manipulator-Controller Cable**:
- Control: Manipulator-Controller cable.
- Motor Power: Welding power cable.
- Gas Hose: (with valve).

- **[Option] Internal Flexible Conduit**:
- For wire feed (for use with drum packing wire only).

### Cantilever Structure
- Makes arm compact and improves accessibility to workpieces.

----

## High Wire Feedability
- **Less Cable Interference**:
- Revolutionary new type of arc welding robot with advantages of both Through-Arm Type and External Type.

### Feature 1: External Flexible Conduit
- **Flexible Conduit**:
- R=large (Torch cable).
- R=small.

- **[Separate Type]**:
- Gentle curve of flexible conduit between wire feeder and torch body achieves stable wire feeding.

### Feature 2: Through-Arm Power Cable
- **[Conventional Type]**:
- Power cable interference can occur depending on the welding position.

- **[Separate Type]**:
- Reduces target position error at weld start and end points.
- New type welding robot achieves even higher quality welds.

----

### Example of Circumferential Welding
- **Suppresses Twist of Wire**:
- Through-arm power cable reduces cable interference.

----

This document outlines the specialized features of a new type of arc welding robot, emphasizing its enhanced structure, performance improvements, and innovative design that combines the best aspects of existing technologies.

# Robot Systems with Integrated Welding Power Source Technology

## Weld Navigation
"Weld Navigation" allows easy parameter setting.

### Easy Setting with Teach Pendant
**Two Easy Steps:**
1. **Pulse**: Unvalid / Valid
2. **Joint Thickness (T1)**:
- **Thickness 2 (T2)**: 3.8
- **Load Length (S)**
- **Throat (a)**
- **Weld Speed**: M.60 Min

### Recommended Conditions
| Parameter         | Value       |
|-------------------|-------------|
| Current           | 138         |
| Voltage           | 16.7       |
| Weld Speed        | 0.80 W/min  |
| Torch Angle (deg) | 45 deg      |
| Offset            | L1 = 0.0    |
|                   | L2 = 0.0    |

**Note:** Screens are subject to change without notice. Torch angle and aiming point are also calculated.

### Rich Welding Parameter Database
Developed through our long experience, the right parameters are automatically adjusted. Leg length and weld speed are also adjustable.

### Weld Navigation
"Weld Navigation" reduces parameter setting time. It recalculates weld current and voltage according to the changes in joint thickness.

### Notes:
- Parameters by Weld Navigation are guidelines only and do not guarantee welding results.
- Consult us for material and processes available with Weld Navigation.

----

## WG Controller with High Performance
### Performance Improvements
- Compared to the conventional model, the WGⅢ controller features a CPU that is 6 times faster and has 4 times more memory capacity, reducing start-up time by 50% to about 30 seconds.

### Improved Maintainability
- **Swivel Rack**: The swivel rack in the case makes maintenance easy and saves space.
- **Cables with Connectors**: Cables with connectors on both ends reduce cable exchange time.

----

### Visual Elements
- **Swivel Rack**: [Description of the swivel rack]
- **Cables with Connectors**: [Description of the cables with connectors on both ends]

This document provides a comprehensive overview of the integrated welding power source technology, emphasizing the ease of use and efficiency improvements offered by the Weld Navigation system and WG controller.

# TAWERS Technology― Various Welding Processes

## TAWERS Welding Process Guide

### MAG Welding Standard
**Note:** 1.2 mm mild steel wire used for this guide.

#### SP-MAG II
- **SP-MAG II**: Super Active MAG
- Low spatter
- **HD-Pulse**: Secondary switching and SP/HS in low-current range achieve stable arc and low spatter welding.

| Speed (cm/min) | Weld Current (A) |
|----------------|-------------------|
| 80             | 80                |
| 40             | 180               |
|                | 220               |
|                | 280               |

- **Weld Types**:
- **Normal-Pulse**:
- Low spatter in short-circuit transfer range
- Spray transfer range
- Droplet transfer (1 pulse-1 drop) in high-current range
- Dip transfer range achieves low spatter.

### CO₂ Welding Standard
**Note:** 1.2 mm mild steel wire used for this guide.

#### MTS-CO₂
- **MTS-CO₂**: Super Active CO₂
- Low spatter in low-current range
- MTS control added to SP-MAG technology reduces spatter of CO₂ welding.

| Speed (cm/min) | Weld Current (A) |
|----------------|-------------------|
| 80             | 80                |
|                | 180               |
|                | 260               |
|                | 320               |

### Super Active TAWERS
- **Super Active Wire Feed Process**: Achieves even lower spatter with high-precision control of wire feed speed.
- **Super Active MAG**
- **Super Active CO₂**

**See the page of “Super Active TAWERS” for details.**

# TAWERS Technology― Various Welding Processes

## SP-MAG for short-circuit mixed gas welding on thin plates
## MTS-CO2 for CO₂ welding

### SP-MAG II
**Super-imposition Control**

Greatly reduces spatter in mixed gas (MAG) welding on thin plates.

#### Spatter Generation
- **Spatter comparison (1 minute at 200 A)**
- Conventional welder (350GB2): 90% spatter
- TAWERS (SP-MAG II): 75% reduction at 150 A (compared with 350GB2)

| Spatter Reduction | Current (A) |
|-------------------|-------------|
| 350GB2            |             |
| SP-MAG I2024      |             |
| SP-MAG II         |             |
| YM-50MT used      |             |

- **Spatter Reduction Graph**

| Spatter Reduction | Current (A) | | |
|-------------------|-------------|---|---|
| 100               |             | | |
| 75                |             | | |
| 50                |             | | |
| 25                |             | | |
| 0                 |             | | |
|                   | 150 A | 200 A | 250 A |

### SP-MAG II Current Waveform
1. **Initial Short-Circuit Control**
- Detects initial short-circuit and then the secondary switching circuit reduces weld current rapidly to prevent micro-short circuit that causes spatter.

2. **Neck Control**
- Detects a neck of the droplet and then the secondary switching circuit reduces weld current rapidly to prevent fuse effect that causes spatter.

3. **HS Control**
- Suppresses weld pool oscillation and prevents micro-short circuit that causes spatter.

4. **SP Control**
- Superimposes the current immediately after a short-circuit release and allows for higher wire-melting speed. This makes the next short circuit smooth and also makes the short-circuit cycle shorter.

### Conventional Mixed-Gas Welding
- **Weld Pool Oscillation**
- Conventional mixed-gas welding shows oscillation in the weld pool, leading to spatter.

### MTS-CO2
**Metal Transfer Stabilization Control**

Reduces spatter by up to 75% using inexpensive CO₂ gas. MTS control added to SP-MAG technology reduces spatter of CO₂ welding.

- **CO₂ Welding Penetration Comparison**

| Process            | Penetration |
|--------------------|-------------|
| Conventional CO₂   | 0.9 mm      |
| MTS-CO₂            | 1.1 mm      |

- **Joint Specifications**
- Joint: Fillet
- Base metal: 2.3 mm mild steel SPCC
- Weld current: 120 A
- Weld speed: 0.3 m/min
- Wire: YGW12 (1.2 mm)
- Shielding gas: CO₂

### Summary
The TAWERS technology, through SP-MAG and MTS-CO₂ processes, significantly enhances welding efficiency by reducing spatter and improving penetration, making it suitable for various applications in thin plate welding.

# TAWERS Technology― Various Welding Processes

## Welding Processes Overview

- **Normal pulse for ultra-low spatter welding**
- **HD-Pulse for high-speed and low-spatter welding**

### HD-Pulse
**(Hyper Dip-Pulse Control)**

Achieves high-speed pulsed welding. Short and narrow arc prevents undercuts during high-speed welding.

#### HD-Pulse Advantages:
- **High speed welding**
- Preventing undercuts during high-speed welding.
- **Dip (Short circuit) transfer**
- Enabling lower heat input with better gap handling capability.
- **Precisely controlled dip timing**
- Reducing spatter.

#### Specifications:
- Base metal thickness: 2.3 mm
- Weld current: 300 A
- Weld speed: 1.1 m/min

**Preventing undercuts with ideal penetration!**

### Type of the Droplet Transfer

| Transfer Type | Description |
|---------------|-------------|
| HD Pulse      | 1 dip by 1 pulse (Short-circuit transfer) |
| Normal Pulse  | 1 drop by 1 pulse (Drop transfer) |

#### Diagram Description:
- **Dip**: Short-circuit transfer
- **Short**: Narrow arc
- **Long**: Wide arc

### Concentrated Arc

#### Spray Transfer Range:
- 280 A or more

### Weld Process Comparison

| Weld Process | SP-MAG Ⅱ | Normal-Pulse | HD-Pulse |
|--------------|-----------|--------------|----------|
| Weld Speed   | Good      | Good         | Excellent|
| Spatter      | Good-Fair | Excellent     | Good     |
| Penetration Pattern | Fair | Good-Fair | Excellent|
| Undercut     | Fair      | Fair         | Excellent|
| Heat Input   | Fair      | Fair         | Good     |
| Gap Handling  | Fair      | Fair         | Good     |
| Overall      | Fair      | Fair         | Excellent|

### Disadvantages:
- **SP-MAG Ⅱ**: Spatter in high-current range.
- **Normal-pulse**: Undercuts in high-speed welding.

**Conclusion**: The HD-Pulse process is ideal for high-current and high-speed welding.

# External Communication (Ethernet)

## Lift Start / Lift End
### Production and Quality Control on LAN
The LAN connection allows you to share welding data with other robots and improve production and quality control.

### Quality Weld Starts and Ends
- **Spatter and Cycle Time Reduction**: The robot lifts up the welding torch quickly at the start and end of the weld. By coordinating the robot motion with the welding waveform and wire feed control, quality and cycle time are improved. (Much quicker than wire retraction.)

#### Lift Start
- **Spatter Reduction**: At arc start

#### Cycle Time Reduction
- **Cycle time reduction at arc end**

----

### Flying Start
Executes arc-on/off programs a little before the torch reaches the weld start/end point to reduce cycle times.

#### Standard Arc Start
- **Weld start point**: Wire feed start
- **Arc start**: The arc is struck the moment the torch reaches the weld start point.

#### Arc Start Retry (for CO₂/MAG)
Detecting a failure of arc start, the robot automatically starts arc ignition again.

- **Wire feed start**: Weld start point
- **Arc start**: Failure of arc start → Arc re-start

----

### Wire Auto Retract
As the robot moves to weld start points, the wire is retracted automatically; thereby, improving arc start.

- **End of a weld**: Wire retraction
- **Next weld point**: Moving toward next weld point
- **Torch Angle Display (Teach Pendant)**: Torch angle is displayed on the screen, making it possible to reduce teaching time and obtain consistent bead appearance.

----

### Wire Stick Auto Release (for CO₂/MAG)
Automatically detects a wire stuck at the end of a weld and re-ignites the arc to release the wire.

----

### Pitch Movement ("Jog settings")
This function enables robot movement at a pre-set distance by every click of the jog dial. This is useful when working in narrow, constricted spaces or in fine-tuning robot position.

----

### Program Test
In Teach mode, the operator can safely verify taught program including welding without switching to Auto mode.

----

### Summary of Features
- **Lift Start/End**: Enhances quality and reduces cycle time.
- **Flying Start**: Reduces cycle times by pre-emptively starting the arc.
- **Wire Auto Retract**: Improves arc start by retracting wire automatically.
- **Wire Stick Auto Release**: Automatically re-ignites the arc if the wire is stuck.
- **Pitch Movement**: Facilitates precise robot movement in tight spaces.
- **Program Test**: Allows safe verification of programs in Teach mode.

# Weld Data Management

## Overview
Big progress toward ideal production and quality control. Samples weld data with an interval of up to 50 microseconds, allowing high-precision monitoring and status/error output. The data can be stored and used for quality control.

### Weld Monitor
Monitors data such as weld current, voltage, and wire feed speed constantly and warns when abnormality is detected.

| Parameter                | Status       | Valid/Invalid | Count |
|--------------------------|--------------|---------------|-------|
| Weld Current             | Valid        | Yalid         | 3     |
| Voltage                  | Invalid      | Invalid       | 7.55  |
| Wire Feed Speed          | Valid        | Yalid         | 0.50  |
| Accumulated Seconds      | Invalid      | Invalid       | bu_U  |

### Optional Software
- **Weld Monitoring (Expanded function)**: Up to 50 weld monitoring conditions can be defined.
- **Weld Data Logging/Recording**: Data such as weld current, voltage, and wire feed speed can be logged according to the preset triggers. The log data can be graphed on the teach pendant and recorded on an SD memory card.

## Welding Data Log
Logs data of weld sections. The log data can be saved for analysis.

### Example of Log Data Analysis
- **Wire target position misalignment caused by production lot change**
- Changes of average current/voltage

| Output Current (A) | Output Voltage (V) |
|---------------------|--------------------|
| 120                 | 20                 |
| 110                 | 19                 |
| 100                 | 18                 |
| 90                  | 17                 |
| 80                  | 16                 |
| 70                  | 15                 |
| 60                  | 14                 |
| 50                  | 13                 |

**Production Time**: 9 to 16 seconds

**Available for defect rate reduction**

## More Advanced Welding System Available
Utilize features such as external communication and large capacity memory.

### Auto Extension Control
**Optional Software**: Synchronous Weaving Low Pulse (Spiral Weaving Included)

- **Spiral weaving movement**: Compensates heat distortion or teaching error of odd-shaped work. Robots detect changes in wire extension and compensate automatically.

| Condition            | Weld Current | Wire Feed Speed |
|----------------------|--------------|------------------|
| Condition A          |              |                  |
| Condition B          |              |                  |

- **Condition B**: Alternates between Condition A/B during weaving, which is ideal for welding of different thickness plates (one for thin plate, the other for thick plate).

### Cooperative Multi-Robot Control
Allows cooperative control between two robots.

# Small Type Arc Welding Robots

## TS Series

### Payload:
- **8 kg**
- **Models:** TS-800 / TS-950

----

### Succeed TAWERS' Welding Performance

- **Various Welding Styles:**
- Super Active TAWERS
- TAWERS-TIG
- TAWERS or others

- **TW Axis: Hollow Arm**
- Torch type selectable between through-arm and external

- **Separate Wire Feeder**
- Free layout

----

### Improve Small Work Productivity

- **Space Saving:**
- 48% smaller footprint (example of one customer, compared with our TM-1100)
- Floor/Wall/Ceiling mount (Ceiling mount type is special specification.)

- **High Speed Despite 8 kg Payload:**
- Maximum motion speed: 540°/s (average for all axes)
